questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with low back pain and stiffness that improves with activity. He has a history of bloody diarrhoea. On examination, there is limited lumbar flexion and tenderness at the sacroiliac joints. His rheumatoid factor is negative, and HLA-B27 is positive. Which of the following is not included in the group of seronegative spondyloarthropathies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rheumatoid arthritis is a seropositive autoimmune disease primarily affecting small joints symmetrically and is usually rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP positive.

  • Seronegative arthritis is a group of arthritic conditions characterised by a negative RA factor and a positive HLA B27 (in most cases).
  • There are 4 seronegative spondyloarthropathies
    1. Ankylosing Spondylitis
    2. Psoriatic Arthritis
    3. Reactive Arthritis
    4. Enteropathic Arthropathy (associated with inflammatory bowel diseases)

Explanation of other options:

Reactive arthritis (Option B): Post-infectious arthritis seen after genitourinary or GI infections; HLA-B27 associated.

Enteropathic arthritis (Option C): Seen with Crohn's or ulcerative colitis; seronegative; often affects spine and sacroiliac joints.

Psoriatic arthritis (Option D): Associated with psoriasis; may have asymmetrical joint involvement; part of the seronegative group.

Key Takeaway:

Rheumatoid arthritis is a seropositive autoimmune arthritis and not classified under seronegative spondyloarthropathies.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman complains of chronic bilateral knee pain that worsens with prolonged activity and improves with rest. Examination reveals crepitus, decreased joint space on X-ray and marginal osteophytes. Which of the following features, if present, would prompt reconsideration of the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The hallmark features of primary osteoarthritis include mechanical cartilage degeneration, osteophyte formation, and subchondral cysts. The presence of pannus formation suggests an inflammatory aetiology like rheumatoid arthritis.

  • Osteoarthritis is a non-inflammatory degenerative joint disease, not associated with synovial proliferation or inflammatory infiltrates.
  • Synovial pannus, a feature of inflammatory arthritides such as RA, leads to cartilage erosion and joint destruction via an autoimmune mechanism.
  • Subchondral cysts and osteophytes are classical radiological findings in OA.
  • Cartilage degeneration is progressive and central to OA pathogenesis.

Key Takeaway:

The presence of pannus or synovial inflammation suggests rheumatoid arthritis, not osteoarthritis.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman presents with knee pain worsened by walking and relieved with rest. On examination, she has crepitus and mild joint line tenderness. Radiograph shows joint space narrowing and osteophyte formation. Which of the following drugs is commonly prescribed for its cartilage-protective effect in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Glucosamine sulfate is a symptom-modifying and structure-modifying agent used in early osteoarthritis for cartilage protection.

  • Osteoarthritis treatment includes analgesics, physiotherapy, and chondroprotective agents.
  • Glucosamine sulfate, Diacerein, and Chondroitin sulfate are used as structure-modifying drugs.
  • These agents may slow cartilage degradation and relieve pain in the early stages.
  • Denosumab and alendronate are used for osteoporosis, not osteoarthritis.
  • Calcium has no role in cartilage repair.

Explanation of other options:

Denosumab (Option A): RANKL inhibitor used in osteoporosis.

Alendronate (Option B): Bisphosphonate inhibiting osteoclastic bone resorption.

Calcium (Option D): Supports bone health, but not cartilage repair in OA.

Key Takeaway:

Glucosamine sulfate is used in early osteoarthritis as a cartilage-protective agent.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with gradually progressive pain in both knees, worsened by activities like walking, stair climbing, and squatting. Clinical image reveals bilateral genu varum deformity. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Bilateral genu varum in an elderly male with activity-related knee pain strongly suggests osteoarthritis.

  • The most common cause of bow legs (genu varum) in older adults is knee osteoarthritis.
  • Mechanical wear and medial joint compartment narrowing cause varus deformity.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis(Option A) more commonly leads to genu valgum or wind-swept deformity.
  • Osteomalacia (Option D)causes Looser zones and affects younger individuals, not typically causing genu varum.
  • Osteoporosis (Option C) leads to kyphotic spine deformities, not varus deformities of the knee.

Key Takeaway:

In adults, bilateral genu varum with knee pain suggests medial compartment osteoarthritis.

choices.text: Rheumatoid arthritis of the PIP joint
Rheumatoid arthritis of the DIP joint

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with gradually progressive nodular swellings over the distal joints of her fingers, as shown in the image below. These swellings are hard, non-tender, and have been slowly enlarging over the years. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The nodular swelling at the DIP joint shown in the image is called a Heberden node, which is characteristic of osteoarthritis.

  • Heberden nodes form at the DIP joints due to osteoarthritic changes.
  • They represent bony outgrowths/osteophytes and are commonly found in elderly females.
  • When similar swelling is seen at the PIP joint, it is termed a Bouchard's node.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis, in contrast, usually spares the DIP joints and involves the MCP and PIP joints.
  • Psoriatic arthritis may involve the DIP but usually has associated nail changes or dactylitis.

Key Takeaway:

Heberden nodes are pathognomonic for osteoarthritis, affecting DIP joints due to osteophyte formation.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents with symmetrical joint pain and swelling in the hands and wrists for the past 6 months. Morning stiffness lasts for over an hour. Radiographs reveal joint space narrowing and marginal erosions. Which of the following is least likely to be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

SLE-associated arthritis (Jaccoud arthropathy) is characteristically non-erosive, unlike most inflammatory arthritides.

  • Rheumatoid arthritis, gout, and pseudogout all lead to erosive joint disease, visible radiographically.
  • In SLE, joint deformities can occur, but without erosion-this is termed non-erosive arthritis or Jaccoud arthropathy.
  • Gout and pseudogout typically cause punched-out or chondrocalcinosis-associated erosions, respectively.

Explanation of other options:

Gout (Option A): Causes "rat-bite" erosions, especially in the first MTP joint.

Pseudogout (Option B): May show cartilage calcification and erosions in chronic disease.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option C): Classically shows marginal erosions and joint space loss.

Key Takeaway:

SLE causes non-erosive arthritis, unlike other inflammatory conditions like RA, gout, and pseudogout.

questions.text: The truth about articular cartilage is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Articular cartilage is composed of hyaline cartilage and is avascular, aneural, and alymphatic.

  • It is hyaline cartilage, not fibrocartilage.( Option C ruled out )
  • No perichondrium is present over articular cartilage.( Option B ruled out )
  • It lacks blood vessels and nerves; hence, articular cartilage itself does not cause pain.( Option A ruled out )
  • Pain in arthritis arises when the subchondral bone is exposed due to cartilage degeneration.

Key Takeaway:

Articular cartilage is avascular and aneural, which is why joint pain in arthritis originates from underlying bone, not the cartilage itself.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with joint pain involving the small joints of the hand and knee. On examination, he has visible joint deformities and restricted range of motion. Radiographs show joint erosion and deformity. Which of the following conditions is least likely to cause this clinical picture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Joint deformities are hallmark features of chronic inflammatory arthritides like RA, ankylosing spondylitis, and psoriatic arthritis, whereas Behcet's disease causes non-deforming arthritis.

  • Rheumatoid arthritis causes symmetrical, deforming arthritis affecting the small joints of the hands and feet.( Option A ruled out )
  • Ankylosing spondylitis leads to axial skeletal deformities, especially spinal fusion.( Option B ruled out )
  • Psoriatic arthritis: May cause dactylitis and deformities like a pencil-in-cup appearance.( Option C ruled out )
  • Behcet's disease: Typically causes non-erosive, non-deforming arthritis, often affecting knees or ankles.

Key Takeaway:

Behcet'ss disease causes non-deforming, non-erosive arthritis, distinguishing it from other inflammatory arthritides.

questions.text: The scar tissue of Patellar Clunk Syndrome causes impingement on
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Patellar Clunk Syndrome occurs post-total knee arthroplasty due to a fibrous nodule forming on the posterior surface of the quadriceps tendon, which impinges on the femoral component during extension.

  • The nodule forms in the intercondylar notch of the femoral component.
  • Impingement occurs during terminal extension, not flexion.
  • Presents with painful clunk during active extension beyond ~30°.
  • Commonly associated with posterior-stabilised knee prostheses.
  • May require surgical excision if symptomatic.

Key Takeaway:

In Patellar Clunk Syndrome, the fibrous nodule impinges on the femoral component during extension, producing the characteristic clunking sound.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with pain, swelling, and morning stiffness in her hand joints for the past 6 months. On examination, there is tenderness and swelling over the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, but the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joints are spared. She also has fatigue and mild anaemia. Which of the following conditions is least likely to involve the DIP joints?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rheumatoid arthritis typically affects the MCP and PIP joints but spares the DIP joints, making DIP sparing a distinguishing feature.

  • Osteoarthritis commonly affects the DIP joints, forming Heberden's nodes.
  • Heberden arthropathy is another term for DIP involvement in osteoarthritis.
  • Psoriatic arthritis may also involve DIP joints, often with nail changes.
  • RA spares DIP joints due to its synovial distribution pattern.

Explanation of other options:

Heberden arthropathy (Option A): Refers to DIP joint involvement in OA.

Osteoarthritis (Option B): Affects DIP, PIP, and first CMC joints.

Psoriatic arthropathy (Option D): Can affect DIP joints, often asymmetrically.

Key Takeaway:

Rheumatoid arthritis spares the DIP joints, which helps differentiate it from osteoarthritis and psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented with B/L hand pain. O/E, the PIP, DIP and 1st CMC joint are involved while the wrist joint is normal. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteoarthritis typically affects the DIP, PIP, and 1st CMC joints while sparing the wrist and MCP joints, helping differentiate it from other arthritides.


Key Takeaway:

Joint involvement pattern helps distinguish osteoarthritis from rheumatoid and psoriatic arthritis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presented to the OPD with pain and stiffness of multiple joints, which is worse in the morning. Her hand X-ray is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rheumatoid arthritis typically presents with symmetrical small joint involvement, prolonged morning stiffness, and characteristic hand deformities.

  • Chronic synovitis leads to ligament laxity and joint deformities.
  • Ulnar deviation at the MCP joints is a hallmark sign.
  • The disease commonly affects women between 30-50 years.
  • Multiple joint involvement
  • Early morning increase in symptoms

X-ray showing the classical ulnar drift of the fingers at the MCP joint

Named Deformities in Arthritis


Explanation of other options:

Osteoarthritis (Option B): Typically involves DIP, PIP, and 1st CMC joints; MCP joints are spared.

Psoriatic arthritis (Option C): Often involves DIP and may show "pencil-in-cup" deformity.

Charcot's joint (Option D): Neuropathic arthropathy with painless deformity and joint instability.

Key Takeaway:

Ulnar deviation at the MCP joints with prolonged morning stiffness is characteristic of rheumatoid arthritis.

choices.text: Fever, weight loss and elevated ESR

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents with multiple joint pain, early morning stiffness lasting over an hour, fatigue, and low-grade fever. Lab tests show anaemia of chronic disease and raised ESR. Which of the following is not a typical feature of inflammatory arthritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Inflammatory arthritis causes periarticular osteopenia due to hyperemia, not sclerosis.

  • Inflammatory arthritis (e.g., RA, SLE) shows periarticular osteopenia on X-ray.
  • Morning stiffness (Option B), constitutional symptoms (fever, fatigue), and raised ESR/CRP (Option D) are typical.
  • Anemia of chronic disease(Option A) is common due to inflammatory cytokines suppressing erythropoiesis.
  • Sclerosis is a radiological hallmark of osteoarthritis, a non-inflammatory condition.

Explanation of other options:

Anaemia of chronic disease (Option A): Common in chronic inflammatory states like RA.

Morning stiffness (Option B): Lasts >1 hour, typical of inflammatory arthritis.

Fever, weight loss, and elevated ESR (Option D): Reflect systemic inflammation.

Key Takeaway:

Sclerosis is a radiological feature of osteoarthritis, not seen in inflammatory arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following hand changes is not seen in Rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pencil-in-cup deformity is seen in psoriatic arthropathy

  • The following are the hand changes in RA
    1. Ulnar drift at MCP joints(Option A ruled out)
    2. Swan Neck deformity
    3. Boutonniere deformity
    4. Hitchhiker's thumb (Option d ruled out)
    5. Z deformity of thumb (Option B ruled out)

questions.text: Identify the deformity shown in the figure.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In this image, there is hyperextension at the PIP joint and flexion in the DIP joint. This is called a swan neck deformity. It is usually seen in RA

  • Boutonniere deformity(Option C ruled out) - There is hyperflexion at the PIP joint and extension in the DIP joint
  • Mallet finger(Option A ruled out) - Traumatic condition, where there is injury to the extensor tendon attachment on the distal phalanx, resulting in a flexion deformity of the DIP.
  • Jersey finger(Option B ruled out) - Traumatic condition, where there is injury to the flexor tendon attachment on the distal phalanx, resulting in an extension deformity of the DIP.
  • Swan neck deformity - there is hyperextension at the PIP joint and flexion in the DIP joint. It is usually seen in RA

Key Takeaway:

Swan neck deformity = PIP hyperextension + DIP flexion → typical of rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Identify the deformity shown in the figure.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In this image, there is hyperflexion at the PIP joint and extension in the DIP joint. This is called Boutonniere deformity
  • Swan neck deformity - there is hyperextension at the PIP joint and flexion in the DIP joint. It is usually seen in RA
  • Mallet finger - Traumatic condition, where there is injury to the extensor tendon attachment on the distal phalanx, resulting in a flexion deformity of the DIP.
  • Jersey finger - Traumatic condition, where there is injury to the flexor tendon attachment on the distal phalanx, resulting in an extension deformity of the DIP.

choices.text: Uniform narrowing of the joint space

questions.text: A 56-year-old female, who has been a known case of rheumatoid arthritis for the last 10 years, presents with bilateral knee pain. Which of the following changes will you not see in her knee X-ray?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Osteophytes are not seen in RA. Osteophytes are a feature of osteoarthritis.

  • Periarticular osteopenia(Option B ruled out) is the earliest radiological sign of RA, caused by increased blood flow and inflammation.
  • Uniform joint space narrowing(Option A ruled out) reflects the systemic, symmetric cartilage loss in RA.
  • Articular erosions(Option C ruled out) result from pannus formation invading the cartilage and bone.
  • Osteophytes, on the other hand, are bony outgrowths seen in OA and are not typical of RA.
  • X-ray findings in RA
    • Periarticular osteopenia (earliest change)
    • Uniform joint space narrowing
    • Erosions of the articular surface
    • Subchondral cysts
    • No osteophytes
    • Deformities

Key Takeaway:

RA causes osteopenia and joint space narrowing, but not osteophyte formation.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female presents with bilateral knee and small joint pain for the last 10 years. O/E, there are deformities of both knees as shown in the figure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows that the patient has genu varum on one side and genu valgum on the other side. This is called wind-swept knees.

  • The most common cause of wind-swept knees in an adult is rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Further, the age of the patient, the female gender of the patient and small joint pain all point towards RA.
  • OA commonly produces bilateral genu varum/bow legs.
  • Osteoporosis produces a kyphotic deformity of the spine.
  • Osteomalacia does not produce knee deformities like this.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with a long-standing history of rheumatoid arthritis presents with complaints of fatigue and joint stiffness. On clinical examination, she has pallor, mild splenomegaly, and bilateral ankle oedema. Laboratory evaluation reveals anaemia and elevated inflammatory markers. Which of the following is not a recognised extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Uveitis is not seen in rheumatoid arthritis but is typically associated with seronegative spondyloarthropathies like ankylosing spondylitis.

  • Scleritis(Option A ruled out) is a recognised ocular manifestation in RA, especially in severe disease.
  • Keratoconjunctivitis sicca(Option C ruled out) is part of secondary Sjögren's syndrome in RA.
  • Amyloidosis(Option B ruled out) is a rare but serious complication of long-standing RA.
  • Other extra-articular features include anaemia, splenomegaly, pleuritis, and peripheral neuropathy.

Key Takeaway:

Uveitis is not an extra-articular feature of RA, helping differentiate it from other inflammatory arthritides like ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: Not true about Spondyloarthropathies
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Seronegative spondyloarthropathies are a group of inflammatory arthritides that are rheumatoid factor negative and HLA-B27 associated.

  • By definition, they are seronegative-i.e., Rheumatoid Factor (RF) negative.
  • They show HLA-B27 positivity(Option B ruled out), axial skeleton involvement, and extra-articular features like uveitis(Option A ruled out).
  • Female predominance is not typical of this group; males are more commonly affected.
  • Rheumatoid arthritis, by contrast, has RF positivity and is more common in females(Option D ruled out).

Key Takeaway:

Seronegative spondyloarthropathies are RF-negative, HLA-B27-positive, and typically affect males, with prominent axial skeleton involvement.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with painful urination, redness in the eyes, and pain in multiple joints. He had a history of diarrheal illness 10 days ago, which was treated with antibiotics. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The triad of urethritis, conjunctivitis, and arthritis following a GI or urogenital infection is characteristic of Reiter’s disease, also called reactive arthritis.

  • It is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy.
  • Most common triggers: Chlamydia, Shigella, Salmonella, Yersinia, Campylobacter.
  • Often affects young males.
  • Features:
    • Urethritis (dysuria, sterile pyuria)
    • Conjunctivitis/Uveitis
    • Arthritis (typically asymmetric and involving lower limb joints)
  • Ritter's disease (Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome) is a pediatric skin condition unrelated to joint disease.

Explanation of other options:

Viral fever (Option A): May cause arthralgia, but not typically with red eye and dysuria.

Ritter's disease (Option B): Staph toxin-mediated skin condition in children.

Antibiotic fever (Option D): Rare; lacks the classical triad seen in this patient.

Key Takeaway:

Reiter's disease is a post-infectious arthritis with the classic triad of urethritis, conjunctivitis, and arthritis-a form of reactive arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Reiter's syndrome
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reactive arthritis is a seronegative spondyloarthropathy triggered by a prior infection. The triggering infection is usually of the GI tract or the UTI. It is also called Reiter's Syndrome

  • There is a triad of
    • Urethritis
    • Conjunctivitis/Uveitis
    • Arthritis
  • There is no stomatitis in Reiter's syndrome.
  • Uveitis is seen in ankylosing spondylitis more commonly.

questions.text: The above image shows a skin lesion on the soles of a 27-year-old male who presents with urethritis, conjunctivitis, and arthritis. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Keratoderma blennorrhagicum is a classical skin lesion seen in reactive arthritis (Reiter's syndrome), often affecting palms and soles.

  • Occurs in young males, especially following GI or urogenital infections.
  • Appears as hyperkeratotic, pustular, or psoriasiform lesions.
  • Often seen in conjunction with circinate balanitis, another hallmark lesion on the glans penis.
  • This patient fits the classical triad of Reactive Arthritis: urethritis, conjunctivitis, and arthritis.

Circinate Balanitis

Explanation of other options:

Subcutaneous nodules (Option A): Found in rheumatoid arthritis, not in reactive arthritis.

Maculopapular rash (Option B): Seen in viral exanthems or drug reactions, not typical here.

Kyrle disease (Option D): A perforating dermatosis seen in diabetes and renal failure, not associated with reactive arthritis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with chronic lower back pain and stiffness, especially in the mornings. He also complains of difficulty bending forward and has had multiple episodes of red eye over the past few months. On examination, his chest expansion is reduced. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ankylosing spondylitis typically affects young adult males and presents with inflammatory back pain, morning stiffness, reduced spinal mobility, and extra-articular features like uveitis.

  • Onset is insidious, often <40 years of age, more common in men.
  • Presents with inflammatory back pain that improves with activity.
  • Reduced chest expansion is a hallmark due to costovertebral joint involvement.
  • Associated with HLA-B27 positivity in most patients.
  • Extra-articular manifestations include anterior uveitis, a red and painful eye.

Explanation of other options:

Gout (Option B): Monoarticular arthritis, typically affecting 1st MTP; no axial skeleton or eye involvement.

Rheumatoid arthritis (Option C): Affects small joints symmetrically; DIP joints are spared, and uveitis is not common.

Osteoarthritis (Option D): Degenerative; affects weight-bearing joints; not associated with uveitis or reduced chest expansion.

Key Takeaway:

A young male with back stiffness, reduced chest expansion, and uveitis is classical for ankylosing spondylitis.
